Dear Mr. Burdell?
If you haven® t already, you will soon receive from the Secretary of the
NAEB a resolution passed by the membership expressing their gratitude for making
available The Cooper Union Forums.
I wanted to add my personal gratitude end that of the Tape Network Head¬
quarters for these splendid forums® Many people have been astounded at th® success
of these forums as radio programs. Long-talk programs have always bean con¬
sidered by radio people as sure death® Continuing success and audience response
to our broadcasts of The Cooper Union Forums disproves this belief most emphatically.
I feel that the wide distribution of these lectures by way of educational radio
stations is a highly significant contribution® We are eternally grateful to The
Cooper Union for maiding them available®
We are working out a method whereby tape copies of the talks will be re¬
turned to Mr® Fairchild for retention on a permanent basis® Eventually we will be
able to supply you with recordings of all the forum programs which we have on file.
We will continue to return a copy of all present and future programs® This seems
a fair gesture on our part since you have continued to supply tape on which to
distribute the programs. Vie are hopeful that having a complete file of these
recordings will be of some use to you®
I h*ave enclosed a recent pamphlet about our Network operation which will
explain some of the details of its origin and methods® We have added about five
stations since the pamphlet went to press, which means that programs such as The
Cooper Unibn Forums can now be heard on almost 80 stations located in all parts of
the country® This is really an almost unbelievable development in the light of
radio broadcasting as we have known it previously®
Again let jtb say that we feel highly privileged to be able to offer The
Cooper Union Forums to such a wide audience® We hope that you, too, see the worth
of this cooperative venture®
Again expressing our deepest gratitude, I am
Cordially,
